abstract: The deal would reshape the Internet consumer services business, where both companies have struggled to compete with Google.
snippet: The deal would reshape the Internet consumer services business, where both companies have struggled to compete with Google.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft said Friday that it has made an offer to buy Yahoo for about $44.6 billion, or $31 a share, in a mix of cash and stock.

abstract: The deal would reshape the Internet consumer services business, where both companies have struggled to compete with Google.
snippet: The deal would reshape the Internet consumer services business, where both companies have struggled to compete with Google.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In a bold move to counter Google’s online pre-eminence, Microsoft said Friday that it had made an unsolicited offer to buy Yahoo for about $44.6 billion in a mix of cash and stock.

byline.original: By Miguel Helft and Andrew Ross Sorkin

abstract: Microsoft said Friday that it would offer $44.6 billion for Yahoo, the ailing search giant. The surprise offer of $31 a share represents a 62 percent premium to Thursday’s closing share price. Yahoo shareholders could elect to receive either cash or stock.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said Friday that it would offer $44.6 billion for Yahoo, the ailing search giant. The surprise offer of $31 a share represents a 62 percent premium to Thursday’s closing share price. Yahoo shareholders could elect to receive either cash or stock.

headline.main: Microsoft Makes $44.6 Billion Bid for Yahoo

abstract: Microsoft is staking a meaningful chunk of its future on its applications platform known as SharePoint, as shown by its recent offer to pay $1.2 billion for a Norwegian search firm. What might be next? Analyst firm The 451 Group takes a look at other potential acquisitions in this area.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is staking a meaningful chunk of its future on its applications platform known as SharePoint, as shown by its recent offer to pay $1.2 billion for a Norwegian search firm. What might be next? Analyst firm The 451 Group takes a look at other potential acquisitions in this area.

abstract: After being served with an unsolicited $44.6 billion takeover bid from Microsoft, Yahoo has reacted cautiously. In a press release early Friday, Yahoo said it will “evaluate this proposal carefully and promptly in the context of Yahoo!’s strategic plans and pursue the best course of action to maximize long-term value for shareholders.”
lead_paragraph: After being served with an unsolicited $44.6 billion takeover bid from Microsoft, Yahoo has reacted cautiously. In a press release early Friday, Yahoo said it will “evaluate this proposal carefully and promptly in the context of Yahoo!’s strategic plans and pursue the best course of action to maximize long-term value for shareholders.”

abstract: No other buyer will be willing to pay more for Yahoo. Since Yahoo’s management will not be able to justify turning down that sort of premium, Microsoft is likely to win the prize.
snippet: No other buyer will be willing to pay more for Yahoo. Since Yahoo’s management will not be able to justify turning down that sort of premium, Microsoft is likely to win the prize.
lead_paragraph: The bottom line: Yahoo will get sold to Microsoft.

abstract: Bear hug letters are an art form. They are designed to put an unwilling takeover target on notice that they are no longer safe, but to fall short of being blatantly hostile.
lead_paragraph: Bear hug letters are an art form. They are designed to put an unwilling takeover target on notice that they are no longer safe, but to fall short of being blatantly hostile.

abstract: For Microsoft, trying to build a new Internet portal-search engine-advertising network-cloud computing company will be trying to make a new interplanetary spaceship out of an old Soyuz capsule and Spacelab while hurtling through the ether. The parts are creaky; the systems are delicate; and the risk of catastrophic failure ever-present.
snippet: For Microsoft, trying to build a new Internet portal-search engine-advertising network-cloud computing company will be trying to make a new interplanetary spaceship out of an old Soyuz capsule and Spacelab while hurtling through the ether. The par...
lead_paragraph: I used to write about bank mergers, and those always struck me as taking two aircraft carriers and building a new one out of the parts.

headline.main: Microsoft Is Building a Spaceship Out of Spare Parts

abstract: When Microsoft announced its $44.6 billion bid to buy Yahoo on Friday, inquiring minds wanted to know whether or not the deal was likely to go through. But many were also asking a different question: Even if the deal is approved, can these two technology titans work together?
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft announced its $44.6 billion bid to buy Yahoo on Friday, inquiring minds wanted to know whether or not the deal was likely to go through. But many were also asking a different question: Even if the deal is approved, can these two technology titans work together?

headline.main: Fitting the Pieces in an Internet Mega-Merger
